Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||automatic slips||"CORRECT||SEE OBS||PLUR"||||||power slips;power-slips||"CORRECT||SEE OBS||PLUR;CORRECT||SEE OBS||PLUR"||"DEF: An air- or hydraulic-fluid-operated device that fits into the opening in the rotary table when the drill stem must be suspended in the wellbore (as when a connection, or trip is being made)."||"CONT: Power slips are pneumatically or hydraulically actuated devices that are operated by the driller at his station, thus dispensing with the manual handling of slips when making a connection."||"CONT: Automatic slips, also called power slips, eliminate the need for roughnecks to set and take out slips manually."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||axial bellows||CORRECT||||||axial expansion bellows||||"DEF: A flexible element either with flange end or butt weld end to absorb any combination of three basic movements, i.e. axial movement, lateral deflection and angular rotation along the axis of the pipe line."||"CONT: [Axial bellows], of the type shown on a wellhead ..., transmit high compressive or tensile forces to the anchors, which must in consequence be sufficiently robust to resist these forces. They provide a rather expensive means of compensation, and are therefore used only where space restrictions prohibit the use of any form of looping - e.g. within a power house building, or in a hot water transmission pipe where vertical looping ... cannot be adopted. Internal metal sleeves greatly reduces steam friction in corrugated axial bellows."||"OBS: bellows: Flexible element of an expansion joint, consisting of one or more convolutions, [usually] formed from thin metal."

The driver's cab is mounted on the end opposite the mast support; thus, the unit must be backed up to the wellhead."||OBS: See carrier rig.

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bag-type preventer||CORRECT||||||bag preventer||CORRECT||CONT: During drilling blowout preventers ... are used to shut in and control the well in the event of gas or oil being encountered at pressures higher than those exerted by the column of mud in the hole. They consist of two or three ram preventers and one bag-type preventer ...||OBS: The topmost preventer is usually of the bag type that will close around any shape. It consists of a thick annular rubber ring sitting in the bowl of a conical-faced piston.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bailer||CORRECT||||||bailing bucket||CORRECT||"DEF: A long cylindrical container, fitted with a valve at its lower end, used to remove water, sand, mud, or oil from a well."||"CONT: The bailer consists of a cylinder 8 to 20 feet (2.5-6 meters) long, which is run into the hole when it is necessary to remove excess water and rock cuttings."||"CONT: ... after drilling a few feet, the bit was pulled out and the cuttings removed with a bailer - an open tube with a valve at the bottom."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bell nipple||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A short length of tubular installed in the top of the blowout preventer.||OBS: The top end of the nipple is expanded - or belled - to guide drill tools into the hole and usually has side connections for the fill line and mud-return line.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bell tap||CORRECT||||||bell;bell screw;bell socket;box bill;die;die collar;box tap||"CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||"||DEF: A cylindrical fishing tool having an upward-tapered inside surface provided with hardened threads.||"CONT: When slipped over the upper end of lost, cylindrical, downhole drilling equipment and turned, the threaded inside surface of the bell tap cuts into and grips the outside surface of the lost equipment."||"CONT: The die collar is made up on the drill pipe and lowered into the hole until it contacts the lost pipe. Rotation of the die collar on top of the pipe causes it to cut threads on the outside of the pipe, forming a firm attachment. Then the pipe is retrieved from the hole."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bent sub||CORRECT||||||angle sub||CORRECT||DEF: A short cylindrical device installed in the drill stem between the bottommost drill collar and a downhole mud motor.||"CONT: The bent sub, or angle sub, is a short piece of drill collar on which the axis of the pin is at an angle relative to the axis of the box."||OBS: The purpose of the bent sub is to deflect the mud motor off vertical to drill a directional hole.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||birdcage||CORRECT||||||bird cage;personnel net;personnel work basket;personnel basket||CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: A small round platform for hauling workers on and off the rig. It is enclosed with wire so no one can fall out, and it is raised or lowered by the crane on the rig."||DEF: A contrivance consisting of interwoven rope lines and a floatable ring on which men ride when being transferred from boat to rig or rig to boat on offshore locations.||"CONT: As the boat came alongside, the crane operator on the rig lowered the birdcage, a small round platform enclosed by wire cables to keep people from falling off. Two or three men at a time climbed aboard the birdcage and were hauled into the air, then lowered to the rig platform, or deck."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bit||CORRECT||||||drill bit;drilling bit;boring bit;boring tool;bore bit;borebit;rock bit||"CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||||||||"||DEF: A drilling tool for cutting through rock.||"CONT: In rotary drilling ... there are two basic types of bit. The rolling-cutter bit shears, chips or grinds the rock as the drill string is rotated; the drag bit and the diamond bit scrape or grind."||"CONT: There are three principal kinds of bits used in rotary drilling: roller-cone bits (rock bits), diamond bits, and fishtail bits (drag bits)."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||boom stop||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: The steel projections on a crane that the boom strikes if raised too high or lowered too far.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bootleg packer||CORRECT||||||||||"CONT: Bootleg packer. A makeshift packer. When it is important to set a string of casing to shut off water between the lowest upperwater sand and the first oil sand, and at the same time it is necessary to run tubing through the open hole to the oil sand, it is often a practice to make an upturned, truncated cone of canvas or leather, the small end of which is the size of the outside of the tubing."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bottom-hole packer||CORRECT||||||bottomhole packer||CORRECT||DEF: A device that prevents communication through the annular space between two strings of pipe and is installed near the bottom of the hole.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bottom-hole plug||CORRECT||||||bottomhole plug||CORRECT||"DEF: A bridge plug or cement plug placed near the bottom of the hole to shut off a depleted, water-producing, or unproductive zone."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bottom-hole pump||CORRECT||||||bottomhole pump;downhole pump||CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: Any of the rod pumps, high-pressure liquid pumps, or centrifugal pumps located at or near the bottom of the well and used to lift the well fluids."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bottom-hole separator||CORRECT||||||bottomhole separator||CORRECT||DEF: A device used to separate oil and gas at the bottom of pumping wells in order to increase the volumetric efficiency of the pumping equipment.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bottom-loading pressure||CORRECT||||||bottom loading pressure||CORRECT||"DEF: The pressure exerted on the bottom hull of a column-stabilized, semisubmersible drilling rig when the rig is submerged."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||box and pin||CORRECT||||||pin and box||CORRECT||"OBS: The male section of the [tool] joint, the pin, is attached to one end of a length of drill pipe, and the female section, the box, is attached to the other end. The tool joint may be welded to the end of the pipe, screwed on, or screwed on and welded."||OBS: The pin is the male coupling end of a drillpipe ... the box is the female coupling end ... as in pin and box.

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bullet perforator||CORRECT||||||bullet-perforating gun;casing perforator;perforator;casing gun;casing-gun;bullet-gun perforator;gun perforator;bullet type gun||"CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||||||"||"DEF: A tubular device that, when lowered to a selected depth within a well, fires bullets through the casing in order to provide holes through which the well fluids may enter."||"CONT: Sometimes, where the bore fluid yield has been disappointing, it has been possible to increase the flow by perforating the production casing by means of a bullet type gun consisting of a special barrel, having four chambers per foot, each housing a hardened 3/4-in steel bullet (19mm) and an explosive charge."||CONT: Perforations are usually made with bullet- or jet-perforating guns.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||bullet||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: The device loaded into a perforating gun to penetrate into casing and cement and some distance into the formation when the gun is fired.||"OBS: bullet perforating: An early perforating method that used a hardened steel bullet or projectile, propelled by an explosive charge, to create a perforation tunnel. This method creates a low-permeability crushed zone and leaves the bullet and associated debris jammed at the end of the tunnel. Jet perforating is now the preferred method."

It is equipped with two long heavy chain links that furnish a means of hanging it on the hoist-line hook. Used to raise and lower collared casing or pipe.

Its use reduces the load imposed on the hoisting mechanism in lowering casing into a wet borehole."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||casing hanger||CORRECT||||||pipe hanger||||CONT: The subassembly of a wellhead that supports the casing string when it is run into the wellbore. The casing hanger provides a means of ensuring that the string is correctly located and generally incorporates a sealing device or system to isolate the casing annulus from upper wellhead components.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||casing hole||CORRECT||||||||||"CONT: Rotary speeds are of the order of 90 to 100 rev/min and penetration rates range from 23 to 40 ft/h (the lower limit applying to the larger diameter surface casing holes, and the upper limit to the deep small diameter holes in the production zone)."||"OBS: casing: Steel pipe placed in an oil or gas well to prevent the wall of the hole from caving in, to prevent movement of fluids from one formation to another, and to improve the efficiency of extracting petroleum if the well is productive."||PHR: surface casing hole

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||casing pipe||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: [Casing] used in oilwells to reinforce the borehole. ||"CONT: To protect potable ground waters in shallow aquifers, both the production and injection wells are lined with steel casing pipe and cemented to the sourrounding rock. This type of well completion prevents the loss of geothermal water to any freshwater aquifers and confines the injection to the geothermal reservoir."||"OBS: Sometimes several casings are used, one inside the other."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||casing string||CORRECT||||||string of casing;string||CORRECT;CORRECT||DEF: The total footage of casing run in a well.||"CONT: Casing is manufactured in lengths of about 30 ft, each length or joint being joined to another as casing is run in a well. The entire length of all the joints of casing is called the casing string."||"CONT: The upper drill pipe is constantly moving vertically through the marine riser, the blowout preventers, the wellhead, and the casing strings."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cementing head||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: An accessory attached to the top of the casing to facilitate cementing of the casing. It has passages for cement slurry and retainer chambers for one or more cementing wiper plugs.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cementing pump||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A high-pressure pump used to force cement down the casing and into the annular space between the casing and the wall of the hole.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||center of buoyancy||CORRECT||||||centre of buoyancy;centre of displacement;center of immersed bulk;center of immersion;center of displacement;center of flotation||"CORRECT||GREAT BRITAIN||OFFICIALLY APPROVED;CORRECT||OFFICIALLY APPROVED||||||||"||"DEF: The center of gravity of the fluid displaced by a floating body (as a ship or mobile, offshore drilling rig)."||DEF: A point through which passes the resultant of all upward forces and by which a floating ship is supported.||"CONT: For monohulls, there are two generic forms for these curves, depending roughly on whether the centre of gravity is above or below the centre of buoyancy."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||centralizer||CORRECT||||||casing centralizer||CORRECT||"DEF: Cylindrical, cagelike device secured around a well casing as it is run to keep the pipe centered in the borehole."||"CONT: Casing centralizers are made with two bands that fit the pipe tightly with spring steel ribs that arch out to press against the wall of the borehole. As the pipe is kept centered, a more uniform cementing job is assured."||OBS: Centralizers are especially useful in deep or deviated holes.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||chain tongs||"CORRECT||SEE OBS||PLUR"||||||||||"DEF: A tool used for turning pipe or fittings of a diameter larger than that which an ordinary pipe wrench will fit. The tool consists of a handle and a releasable chain that is placed around the outer circumference of the pipe or fitting. The chain grips the pipe firmly, allowing it to be turned by hand."||"CONT: Chain tongs are hand tools used on pipe of small diameter and consist of a lever having steel teeth and a special chain on one end, the chain being drawn around the pipe and latched."||OBS: chain tongs: term rarely used in the singular (chain tong).
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||change rams||"CORRECT||VERB PHRASE"||||||||||"DEF: To take rams out of a blowout preventer and replace them with rams of a different size. When the size of a drill pipe is changed, the size of the rams must be changed to ensure that they seal the pipe when closed."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||chase threads||"CORRECT||VERB PHRASE"||||||||||DEF: To clean and deburr the threads of a pipe so that it makes up properly.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cheater||CORRECT||||||snipe||||DEF: A length of pipe fitted over a wrench handle to increase the leverage of the wrench.||"OBS: However, use of a larger wrench is usually preferred."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||choke line||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: An extension of pipe from the blowout-preventer assembly, used to direct well fluids from the annulus to the choke manifold."||CONT: In the event of high pressure kick with the drill string in the hole the blowout preventer is closed around the drill pipe and the mud is circulated down the drill string and back to the mud tanks through the choke line and back-pressure manifold.||OBS: choke: An orifice installed in a line to restrict the flow or control the rate of production.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||choke manifold||CORRECT||||||back-pressure manifold||CORRECT||DEF: The arrangement of piping and chokes through which drilling mud is circulated when the blowout preventers are closed to control the pressures encountered during a kick.||"CONT: The manifold consists of a series of valves and chokes. ... There are usually at least two chokes on a back-pressure manifold, either of which can be isolated to permit the cone and seat to be changed."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||circulating head||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: An accessory attached to the top of the drill pipe or tubing to form a connection with the mud system to permit circulation of the drilling mud.

When properly interpreted, this log provides a very accurate way to measure depths in a well."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||come-along||CORRECT||||||comealong||CORRECT||DEF: A manually operated device used to tighten guy wires or move heavy loads.

The rig is highly transportable and is estimated to enable Heritage to drill an exploration well for less than one third of a conventional well."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||completion equipment||CORRECT||||||||||CONT: An operator [of a well] may ... conduct a wireline or coiled tubing operation through a christmas tree located above sea level where ... the operation does not ... result in damage to the completion equipment or pressure retaining barriers ...||OBS: completion: Indicates all the operations performed on a specific producing stratum beginning with drilling and ending with definitive production.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||compound||"CORRECT||NOUN"||||||||||"DEF: The mechanism for transmitting power from the engines to the pump, drawworks, and other machinery on a drillling rig."||"CONT: A compound is composed of clutches, chains and sprockets, belts and pulleys, and a number of shafts, both driving and being driven."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||conductor pipe||CORRECT||||||conductor;conductor string;conductor casing||"CORRECT||NOUN;CORRECT;CORRECT"||"DEF: A string of large diameter casing, typically 20 inches OD (508 mm), but sometimes larger, extending from the cellar deck in a jack-up drilling rig down into the borehole for about 60 metres."||CONT: The bit is fastened to the string ... The string hangs inside a casing called a conductor pipe.||CONT: Drilling is started by attaching a short drill collar and a large bit to the kelly and drilling a hole to about 50 ft. A length of large size casing is run into this and cemented to the formation. This is called the conductor.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cone bit||CORRECT||||||cone rock bit||CORRECT||DEF: A roller bit in which the cutters are conical in shape and have teeth for cutting the work.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||connector housing||||||||sonde support||||"OBS: Source for  connector housing : Petroleum Engineer (International), 1983, Nov. 15, p. 22."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||continuous poteclinometer dipmeter||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: [A device] for continuously recording parameters such as inclination, orientation of this inclination, and azimuth of one of the correlation."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||continuous stirred tank reactor||CORRECT||CSTR||CORRECT||||||"CONT: One experiment was designed to study the effect of bottom withdrawal and additive composition and concentration on reactor bed behaviour, product yields and properties. The other two were performed with pitch from light Arabian oil using a continuous stirred tank reactor (CSTR)."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cooling tower||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A structure in which air contact is used to cool a stream of water that has been heated by circulation through a system. The air flows counter-currently or cross currently to the water.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cordage||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: All the ropes used on a ship or offshore drilling rig.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||core barrel||CORRECT||||||core drill;hollow-core extrusion equipment||"CORRECT||"||DEF: A device used in rotary drilling to cut cores.||"CONT: The core barrel, varying in length from 25 to 60 ft, is run at the bottom of the drill pipe in place of a bit or in conjunction with a special bit."||"OBS: Also variously called  core drilling machine and  core cutting machine. "
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||core bit||CORRECT||||||coring bit;core cutterhead;core-cutter head;core cutter head||"CORRECT;CORRECT||||"||"DEF: A hollow, cylindrical boring bit for cutting a core in rock drilling or in boring unconsolidated earth material."||DEF: The element of the core-barrel assembly that cuts the core from the formation.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||core drill||"CORRECT||VERB PHRASE"||||||||||"DEF: To drill shallow wells of small diameter for geological information, usually in the bottom of an already existing wellbore. This provides a continuous core of the depth drilled."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||core lifter||CORRECT||||||core catcher;core catching finger;core grabber;core gripper;core spring;ring lifter;spring lifter;split-ring lifter;core extractor||"CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||"||"DEF: A spring clip at the base of the core barrel which grips the core, enabling it to be broken off and brought out of the hole."||CONT: The function of a core lifter or core catcher is to catch core as it enters the core barrel and to retain it through wedging action.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||corkscrew||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A fishing tool resembling a corkscrew.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||correcting wedge||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A deflection wedge used to deflect a crooked borehole back into its intended course.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||counterbalance weight||CORRECT||||||counterweight||CORRECT||DEF: A weight applied to compensate for existing weight or force.||"CONT: On pumping units in oil production, counterweights are used to offset the weight of the column of sucker rods and oil on the upstroke of the pump and the weight of the rods on the downstroke."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cracker||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: A manila cable, usually 100 feet long, placed between a string of tools and a wire cable to give the desired elasticity."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cross bit||CORRECT||||||X bit;star bit
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cross-pit stacker||||||||||||CONT: The machine [bucket excavator] will feed directly into a long cross-pit stacker.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crosshead||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: The block in a mud pump that is guided to move in a straight line and serves as a connection between the pony rod and connecting rod.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crossover joint||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A length of casing with one kind of thread on the field end and a different thread in the coupling.||CONT: Crossover joints are used to make a changeover from one thread to a different one in a string of casing.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crossover||"CORRECT||NOUN"||||||||||DEF: A connection between two channels or passages.||"CONT: Crossovers are used in packers, in piping, and in other special devices in flow systems."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crow's nest||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: Any elevated walkway where men work (e.g., on the top of a derrick or refinery tower)."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crowfoot||CORRECT||||||crow's foot||CORRECT||"DEF: A tool with a sideclaw, for grasping and recovering broken rods in deep boreholes."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crown block||CORRECT||||||crown pulley;crown wheel;crown||CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: A pulley, set of pulleys, or sheaves at the top of a drill derrick on and over which the hoist and/or other lines run."||"CONT: The crown block is an assembly of sheaves mounted on beams at the top of the derrick. The drilling cable is reeved over the sheaves of the crown block alternately with the sheaves of the traveling block, which is hoisted and lowered in the derrick by means of the drilling cable."||"CONT: At the top of the derrick there is a crown block containing pulley wheels over which are run three steel cables: the casing line ..., the sand line ..., and the drilling line ..."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||crown pulley||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A pulley whose diameter is greater at the middle than at the edges of its face. This crown tends to prevent the belt from running off the pulley provided the belt is not slipping.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cutter||CORRECT
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||cutting edge||CORRECT||||||cutting point||||CONT: Drilling machines use a drilling tool that has cutting edges at its point.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||dead end||"CORRECT||NOUN"||||||||||DEF: The end of a drilling line or cable made fast to some stationary part of the drill rig or to a deadman.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deadline tie-down anchor||CORRECT||||||deadline anchor||||DEF: A device to which the deadline is attached and securely fastened to the mast or derrick substructure.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deadline||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: The part of a block-and-tackle cable from the traveling block to the deadline anchor.||OBS: deadline: So called because this part of the line does not move.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deadman||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: A buried log, timber, concrete block, or the like serving as an anchor to which a pulling line can be attached."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deep drilling rig||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: Equipment capable of reaching four miles or more beneath the surface.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deep-well pump||"CORRECT||OFFICIALLY APPROVED"||||||deep well pump||CORRECT||DEF: A production pump designed for service in a deep well.||OBS: deep-well pump: term officially approved by the Lexicon Project Committee (New Brunswick).
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deflecting wedge||CORRECT||||||deflection wedge;whipstock||CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: A long, steel casing using an inclined plane to cause the bit to deflect from the original borehole at a slight angle."||"CONT: Whipstocks are used in controlled directional drilling, for straightening crooked boreholes, and for sidetracking in order to avoid unretrieved fish."||"OBS: All such devices are basically long, tapered, concave metal plugs which can be set at a predetermined point and bearing in a borehole ..."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||deflection bit||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: A taper bit, generally a bullnose type, used to drill down past the deflecting wedge when deflecting a borehole."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||depthometer||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A device used to measure the depth of a well or depth at a specific point in a well (as to the top of a liner or to a fish) by counting the turns of a calibrated wheel rolling on a wireline as it is lowered into or pulled out of a well.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||derrick floor||CORRECT||DF||"CORRECT||SEE OBS"||rig floor;drill floor||CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: The area [of a derrick] immediately above the substructure on which the drawworks, rotary table, etc. rest."||OBS: DF: The abbreviation for derrick floor; used in drilling reports.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||desander||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A centrifugal device for removing sand from drilling fluid to prevent abrasion of the pumps.||"OBS: A desander may be operated mechanically or by a fast-moving stream of fluid inside a special cone-shaped vessel, in which case it is sometimes called a hydrocyclone desilter."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||desilter||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: A centrifugal device, similar to a desander, used to remove very fine particles, or silt, from drilling fluid to keep the amount of solids in the fluid to the lowest possible level."||"OBS: The lower the solids content of the mud is, the faster the rate of penetration."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||detachable bit||CORRECT
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||diamond bit||CORRECT||||||crown;boart bit;boart-set bit;bort bit;bort-set bit;bortz bit;bortz-set bit;diamond crown;diamond set coring crown||CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||DEF: A rotary-drilling bit studded with diamonds (usually borts).||"CONT: In harder rocks, diamond bits are essential. There are several types of diamond set coring crowns, as they are often called ..."||OBS: [The diamond bit] is used for drilling extremely hard rock or in a program of continuous coring.

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||die nipple||CORRECT||||||fishing tap;male fishing tap;tap;fishing taper||"CORRECT;CORRECT||NOUN||||"||DEF: A thread-cutting tool to cut threads inside a casing or other hollow part that is to be fished from a borehole.||OBS: [This] device ... is similar to the die collar but with external threads.||"OBS: ... the overshot is used to grip the pipe on the outside, while the tap screws into heavy-wall pipe such as drill collars and grips it with its tapered surface."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||differential fill-up collar||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A device used in setting casing. It is run near the bottom of the casing and automatically admits drilling fluids into the casing as needed so the casing sinks rather than floats in the well.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||differential fill-up shoe||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: A device similar to a differential fill-up collar, except it is run on the bottom of the casing and is incorporated into the guide shoe."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||dip meter||CORRECT||||||dipmeter||CORRECT||DEF: A device used to determine the angle of dip and direction of geologic formations.

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||displacement||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: The weight of fluid (as water) displaced by a freely floating body (as an offshore drilling rig), such weight being exactly equal to the weight of the rig and everything on board."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||diverter||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A system used to control well blowouts encountered at relatively shallow depths and to protect floating rigs during blowouts by directing the flow away from the rig.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||doodlebug crew||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: The workers who dig seismograph holes.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||doodlebug||"CORRECT||NOUN||JARGON"||||||||||DEF: Any of the various devices used in searching for petroleum deposits.||"CONT: Dowsing is the action of a person - called the dowser - using a rod, stick, or other device - called a dowsing rod, dowsing stick, doodlebug (when used to locate oil) or divining rod - to locate such things as underground water, hidden metal, buried treasure, oil, lost persons, or golf balls, etc."||OBS: doodlebug: Slang term.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||doodlebug||"CORRECT||VERB||JARGON"||||||||||DEF: Prospect for oil with any device from a divining rod to the newest geophysical equipment.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||double board||CORRECT||||||||||"DEF: The derrickman's working platform, or monkeyboard when located at a height in the derrick or mast equal to two lengths of pipe joined together."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||double extra-strong pipe||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A pipe incorporating twice as many safety design factors as normally used.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||double-acting piston||CORRECT||||||||||"CONT: Most mud pumps have double-acting pistons, but some have single-acting pistons that function as plunger."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||double-acting pump||CORRECT||||||||||"CONT: A typical mud pump is a double- or triple-acting, two- or three-cylinder, piston pump whose pistons travel in replaceable liners and are driven by a crankshaft actuated by an engine."

Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||drag bit||CORRECT||||||blade bit;bit with wings;bit with blades||CORRECT;CORRECT;CORRECT||"DEF: Various kinds of rigid steel bits provided with fixed (as contrasted to the movable or rolling cutting points of a roller bit) and sometimes replaceable cutting points, which are rotated to drill boreholes in soft to medium-hard rock formations."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||drainage channel||||||||||||"CONT: The water is then discharged to a drainage channel adjacent to the resort. The water goes into a collection pond and then is used ... for irrigation of crops ... Excess water, not used by the resort is bypassed directly into the local sewer line serving a nearby residential area, and ends up in a sewage lagoon adjacent to the property."
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||drawworks||CORRECT||||||draw works||CORRECT||DEF: The hoisting mechanism on a drilling rig. It is essentially a large winch that spools off or takes in the drilling line and thus raises or lowers the drill stem and bit.||"DEF: Nerve center of the drilling rig; principal parts include hoisting drum, brakes, clutches, catheads, and control panel ..."||"CONT: On a drilling rig, the hoist that raises and lowers the drill stem is called  drawworks. "
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||dress||"CORRECT||VERB"||||||||||DEF: To sharpen or repair items of equipment (as drilling bits and tool joints) in order to make them ready for reuse.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||drift indicator||CORRECT||||||||||DEF: A device dropped or run down the drill stem on a wire line to a position just above the bit to measure only the inclination of the well off vertical at that point.
Equipment (Oil and Natural Gas Extraction)||drill collar||CORRECT||DC||"CORRECT||SEE OBS"||drilling collar;striking bar||"CORRECT||"||"DEF: A heavy thick-walled tube, usually steel, used between the drill pipe and the bit in the drill stem to weight the bit in order to improve its performance."||CONT: At the bottom end of the drill pipe are extra-heavy sections called drill collars that serve to concentrate the weight on the rotating bit.||OBS: Sometimes drill collars are called simply collars.
